Fields.MenuText: They're worried about you. So am I. You doing okay, Ashigara?
Apparently some of the crew think you've had a stick up your ass recently.
Something lingering from our encounters with Cowardice?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. Mostly. Got some things on my mind. A weird energy I can't burn off.
If I do, I'm going to work it out and beat them with it. Damn gossips.
Hell if I know. I'm frustrated that she keeps coming back like a cockroach, sure enough.
Korrrra! Anyone falls down on the job, pick 'em up! And if you sleep, you can damn well stay there for the real wolves to chow down on!
@BATTLE
Hey, hasn't Ane-san been a bit on edge recently?
She has seemed a bit off. She's usually a bit more relaxed.
Still good about minding our off time, at least.
I wonder if it's because of her duels with Cowardice?
Eh? How do you figure? We get the better of Cowardice each time we fight, you know.
Korrrraa! If you have time to be gossiping like old women, you've got time to be making yourself useful!
Gah! Ane-san!
Oyabun, too!
Shut it, bakayarō! She told us not to call Kanchou that.
Moushiwake arimasen, Kanchou, Ane-san!
You better damn run! If I catch you, you'll be cleaning the goddamn engine room till I can eat off the deck! Koooorraaa!
Kuso! Kanchou! Did you, uh... hear any of that?
Hmmph. Acting like a bunch of punks instead of wolves.
There's no sense being too harsh on them as long as everything's up to standard or better.
You're not wrong, Kanchou. Come on, let's find some tea and have a talk.
We could both use a little down time.
You know, Ashigara, I've noticed some changes in the crew recently.
The foreign sailors are using more Japanese, for a start, and I've seen tattoos peeking past collars.
What's a sailor without an iron heart, a salty mind, and a tattooed body, Kanchou?
Besides, morale is doing well, so as long as the sailors are happy...
It's arrogance I'm worried about. You're confident, but they might misstep if they try to follow in your wake.
I think they'll be fine, Kanchou. They have you for an example, too.
Speaking of tattoos, do you have a tattoo or two, Ashigara?
Sure do, Kanchou. Why? Want to see?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Very yes.
Wouldn't that just be someone painting on your hull?
I'll show you mine if you show me yours.

Fields.DialogueText: You can't just ask to see a back piece so easily!
Huh!? It's entirely different, Kanchou!
Maybe I'll take you up on that offer soon, Kanchou.
Anyway, it's good for morale. It's a mark of belonging, of brotherhood.
Even amongst the women?
For onna-musha, brotherhood is one of the rare privileges we get to enjoy that others do not.
I... Tch. Kanchou, I hate to interrupt, but we're about to be needed on the bridge.
Sensing an enemy fleet?
I can't decide if I hear them, smell them, or... "feel" them first, somehow. Disgusting sensation, though.
Well, let's drive them off for your health, eh?
@BATTLE
Come on! The quicker you bring her down, the quicker we can enjoy our kill!
@BATTLE
Hmm. That's not right. Sailors lounging on deck smoking... XO!
Yes, Captain?
I want those idiots on deck, not hanging around with their feet over the side.
Aye, Captain. But--
Kanchou, I let them do that. This is their home. They're to use rope to avoid a man overboard.

Fields.MenuText: I don't give a damn. It's dangerous.
Them being tied to the hull won't help if we go to battle stations on short notice.
I'm not sure I like this, but if you're confident...

Fields.DialogueText: Relax, Kanchou. We're taking precautions while letting them relax in their own way. We may die before sunset, after all.
They're good sailors. They know their business.
I am, Kanchou. These are my fine wolves, after all. My boys and girls will be okay.
It really is giving them a chance to relax a bit more. They love the sea. I can't blame them for that.
Mhmm. I'm still worried about a call to action stations.
My fine wolves won't be caught on deck with their pants rolled up when the call to battle comes.
See that they aren't. We're all counting on you.
Oi, Kanchou! Over here!
That's quite the wolfish grin on your face, Ashigara.
Good news, Kanchou. Intelligence reports that my favorite prey is in the area.
Cowardice is back? I'm surprised she's willing to show her face.
Cowardly and stupid. Quite the combo!

Fields.MenuText: Keep your guard up. Cowards tend to be sneaky too.
This whole thing would be easier if they'd just stay dead.
I wonder why she's back? They always have a reason, even if we don't get it.

Fields.DialogueText: She won't get a knife between our ribs. You have my word.
Hah! Ain't that the truth?
I doubt it matters that much. We find them. We sink them. End of story.
Hopefully the scout planes will get us a location soon and...
Kanchou! Ane-san! We've got Morganas in sight!
Get a bearing on that plane and set us a course! Helm, bring us to battle speed once we're a few miles out.
Fog on the horizon! Kuso! Incoming!
Hah! They can't hit accurately at that range!
Battle stations! Flank speed towards the enemy!
That's the ticket! She wants a sniper duel, but she's getting a brawl!
@BATTLE
Teme! Cowardice is back! How did she pop up again so quickly?
Damn it, she outmaneuvered us. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Chikushō! How did this happen?
Even light shells from naval-caliber guns can kill crewmates. Cowardice attacked at max range before we even turned to engage.
I know that! They got caught out on deck even as the alarm sounded...
... Probably out smoking. They didn't even make it to their stations.
Corpsman! Over here! You hang on.
I... can't. I'll cut my pinky off later to make up for it. It's stopped hurting. I don't think that's a good sign.
Just stay conscious, damn you! I...
... She's gone limp. Where's that corpsman?
Ashigara... she's gone.
I know! Damn it.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay?
There's others we can be helping. We'll mourn later.
She did her duty. May she be received in the next life with honor.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm fine. It's not my guts spilled all over the deck.
You're right. Damn it, where are those corpsmen!?
If her ancestors won't receive her properly, maybe she'll be reborn as the wolf she died as.
It really is always this close, isn't it? Just an inch or two's difference between life and death.
It's the warrior's lot.
So it is. Hmm. The corpsmen are here. I need to go.
I haven't seen her affected by death like that before.
I'll have to check on her later.
Kanchou-dono! We could use some help over here!
Ane-san...
I heard you cleared the lookouts out of this post on the mast.
I told them not to run their mouths about it, either.
They seemed worried about you. I'm worried too.
You don't need to be. It's nothing. Just... something about that sailor dying.
We've both had men and women die under our command before.
I don't think I'd ever held someone as they died, though.

Fields.MenuText: It was good that you were at the service. The sailors appreciated it.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a certainty. An opportunity for their spirits to live on with their brothers. A sentinel of the fallen, and a guardian of the living.

Fields.MenuText: It does feel a bit different, especially if you're right next to them when the attack hits.

Fields.DialogueText: On some level I'm right next to all of them when they're hit. Caught with my guard down no matter where I am.

Fields.MenuText: As you've said before, death is part and parcel of our service as bushi.

Fields.DialogueText: It is, but so is being very hard to kill. If one sells their life, one should sell it dearly.
I'm not sure what's gotten into me. I'm not even human. Yet here I am, smoking and contemplating.
In a way, I'd say you're the most human of us all.
I'm not cut out for this heavy thinking. Some Kami have insight into our nature. I'm not one of them.
They might be wrong, too. Lots of humans think they have insight into our nature.
Hah, a fair point. Still. Kanchou, what do you think happens if I'm slain?
There's a lot to that question. I hear from other Belles that they remember their previous incarnations. Partially, anyway.
So maybe you'll just rest. Maybe you'll return as a new ship when you're needed.
That wouldn't be so bad.
Enough of this, though. I... Kuso.
Kanchou! Look! On the horizon!
Blast. They really have terrible timing.
@BATTLE
Korrraa! Out of my ocean, damn you!
@BATTLE
You chased the lookouts off again.
I needed to meditate. I can stand the watch just fine.
So you say. That's a serious look on your face, though. Something wrong?
Kanchou, what do you think happens to humans when they die?

Fields.MenuText: I can't rightly know. No one can. That's why it's scary.
I believe there's something that comes after this world. Something more.
Humans... everything with a soul, really... they're reborn until they learn what they need to.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah... darkness, the unknown. I can understand that. On some level. Even if I'm not quite human. Or mortal.
If I'm good enough, brave enough... maybe I can earn that type of next life, too.
Hmm. That even accounts for Kami. Seems frustrating... but then, if learning the lessons were easy, it wouldn't be important.
Why the dark thoughts today, Ashigara?
Just reflecting. There's a lot of dead since the start of the Funayūrei war.
So I prayed for peace for their souls... and then considered what peace might mean.
A worthy enough goal.
It hasn't settled my thoughts, unfortunately.
I have... new emotions. Ones I'm not used to. I need to calm the seas inside somehow.
Can I ask you about this another time, Kanchou? I need to think more.
Any time, Ashigara.
Korrra! Come on! Put your  backs into it!
What's going on, Ashigara?
Ah, Kanchou! Just a little sparring drill.
I thought sweating a bit might help everyone remember they're alive.
Don't wear the next watch out too much.
Of course not, Kanchou. Care to join us? I'll be your partner.

Fields.MenuText: Sure, why not?
I'm reasonably certain that you're going to trounce me.
Are you sure about that offer, Ashigara?

Fields.DialogueText: Someone get Kanchou a sword!
We learn even in defeat.
Heh. Did I make a mistake, perhaps? That sounded like a challenge, Kanchou.
Let's see, shall we?
Good grip. Decent stance. Very well. Be--
*ALARM*
I swear they have some sort of sense that lets them detect fun.
On the plus side, what could be better than actual battle to get the blood up?
It's different than doing it in person, put a little gun duel does sound fun.
Come on! To your stations!
Come, my fine wolves - we have guests to entertain! I'll not have our hospitality found wanting.
@BATTLE
Not a moment too soon. Keep an eye on those friendlies, Ashigara!
Way ahead of you!
@BATTLE
Ship adrift! Looks like a cargo ship, Captain!
Helm, adjust our course. Bring us alongside so we can check for survivors.
There's no one alive on that ship. Look how it's moving... and there. Blood on the fo'c'sle.
Damn. That's quite a bit of blood now that I get my spyglass on it. But no bodies...
Must have been the work of the Funayūrei we just engaged. Injustice, maybe? She does like her spectacle.

Fields.MenuText: She likes spectacle where people can see her.
Not enough blood for full-on beheadings. Besides, Injustice likes to display the bodies.
It's a lot of blood, but not enough to account for a crew of a cargo ship that size.

Fields.DialogueText: True, she does like to make her statements and show off. Damn circus act.
Right, not nearly grisly enough for her. Who, then?
You're right. That is odd. I wonder if they left the cargo intact?
Chief, boarding party away. Find survivors and police up supplies.
The dead don't need it, but we can still make use of it.
Leave any food unless it's sealed. It might be tainted.
It warms my heart when you have a proper sense of paranoia, Kanchou.
Right away, Kanchou, Ane-san.
Still, picking the bones of the Morganas' kill?
Wolves shouldn't turn their noses up at good meat. It's not like the dead are using it.
I'll make sure Chief shakes the boarding party down for personal effects when they get back.
No need to loot off the dead, but the actual cargo will just go to waste otherwise.
Depending on what it is, it still might.
Judging by the markings I'd say they're a small, independent freighter. They might have all sorts of goodies we can barter or use.
All right, sounds like you know what you're doing at the very least. I know you're not terribly greedy.
Trust me, Kanchou, I have everything under control. I'm going to seize every advantage I can get for my fine wolves.
Whatever I do is for the good of the fleet, and that's a promise.
I'll hold you to that.
Is this all? Maybe these oni are finally giving us a break.
@BATTLE
Seems like it's been quiet today.
KORRRRRRRAAA!
You just had to say something. I'll look into it. You have the conn.
Oh, look, Kanchou arrived just in time to stop me from skinning you myself!
What's going on here? Ashigara, sheathe your damn sword!
This fool was sleeping on watch.
Is that true, sailor?
Yes, Captain. I drifted off for a moment.
Having a grand old time doing it, too.
Well, I know how to deal with failures like yours. Take this. You know what to do. Get out of my sight till then.
Hai, Ane-san!
Ashigara... was that your tantō?
What if it was?

Fields.MenuText: Damn it, Ashigara, it's the 20th century!
I believe I told you not to maim my sailors.
Good. A little something to remember this incident by.

Fields.DialogueText: And? For some, discipline is a lesson. For others, it's a lifetime.
I never have, and I hopefully never will. He'll do it himself.
There's something to be said for the old ways, eh, Kanchou?
Yubitsume might be the old way, but it is a way. Besides, it's just a fingertip.
If I was really doing it the old way, I'd be demanding an entire pinky finger.
More modernly, one of those is used for a bit more than supporting a sword, so a tip will do.
Trust me, Kanchou, I'll handle it. That sailor won't make this mistake again... and others will learn from his example.
... Fine. But I'll be monitoring this situation closely.
Voices in the corridor... Wait, are they talking about Ashigara?
Did you hear about what happened to one of the lookouts?
Right. Yubitsume, huh? Ane-san must have been furious.
We should be, too. Falling asleep on watch puts us all at risk.
True... but isn't yubitsume going a little too far? That sailor's still nursing that wound.
Maybe. But it's better this way, isn't it? No paperwork; failure, recompense.
Still... seems a bit harsh for a Kami.
You're not Japanese. The gods can be just as harsh as any others.
I suppose you're right. Seems a bit demonic, though.
Come on. Back to work.
You can come out now.
How'd you know?
Saw your tail peek out around the corner.
Damn traitorous limb. Well? What do you think of that?

Fields.MenuText: Seems like some of the new recruits might even be scared of you.

Fields.DialogueText: A little fear is good for the soul.

Fields.MenuText: Would you rather be respected or feared, Ashigara?

Fields.DialogueText: In a perfect world, I'd be respected and feared.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like some of our sailors could stand toughening up a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: The age of wooden ships and iron men is long gone, eh?
Still, what they said... Maybe I'm not providing enough guidance?
In what way?
Well, I am a kami, or at least they see me as one. Even the foreigners are slowly picking up chunks of Shinto.
Maybe... as a martial spirit, I should be more proactive in offering guidance.
You know, show them the right path so it's a hundred percent clear what one's duty is. That would make personal acts of penance mean more.
It couldn't hurt. Plus it might lessen the number of my sailors who are short fingertips.
You don't need to make it sound common, Kanchou. My sailors are fairly well disciplined as it is.
I'd rather have no disciplinary issues than few, whether it's handled extrajudicially or not.
*ALARM*
Hold that thought. Some fools need a far more enjoyable kind of discipline!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I've made a decision! I'm going to study bushido and ensure I'm fully embodying Japan's martial values.
As a Kami I need to be leading the ship's complement. An example, not just a specter of discipline.
They shouldn't fear my justice. They should know they've done wrong and offer themselves to it.
That's the way of a real warrior. If they're slinking away from such things or flinching, I've failed them.

Fields.MenuText: What is that going to entail?
I think you're expecting a bit much of junior enlisted.
Good. A little more steel in their spines will benefit everyone.

Fields.DialogueText: For now? More meditation, kenjutsu, and a fair bit of reading.
Maybe. But it's better to have expectations and ensure you meet your own standards.
I'm glad you agree, Kanchou.
I've sent off for a couple of books.
Till then I'm rereading my copy of the Go Rin no Sho, by the kensei Miyamoto Musashi.
The Book of Five Rings? Not a bad place to start.
I figure anyone skilled enough to be named a sword saint probably knows what they're talking about.
One of the manuscripts I ordered is his. The Dokkōdō - the path of walking alone - is a bit more aesthetic and Buddhist than I want.
I figure it's still worth reading through to gain more of his mindset later in life.
The Japanese mix of religions is always interesting to look at. Shinto and Buddhism are so tightly intertwined.
I heard a priest sum it up as "Shinto in life, Buddhism in death," which isn't far wrong.
Another Kami I correspond with occasionally is sending me a copy of the Hagakure. It's supposed to be an excellent text on bushido.
Sounds interesting. You'll have to share your findings with me. Over a cup of tea or sake, perhaps.
Hai, Kanchou. With pleasure!
*ALARM*
I swear you can almost time a pocket watch by them.
At least they're punctual. Be nice if they announced themselves before opening fire.
Heh. I'm sure Kongou-sama is most incensed by their utter lack of manners.
And you?
I'm a wild wolf, Kanchou. I don't give a damn about their manners, but having the poor sense to challenge me? That type of hubris I must punish!
@BATTLE
Gaaaaaaah! SHINE'E!
Having trouble, Ashigara?
Kuso. Err. Kanchou! Did you, uh... hear that?
Pretty sure most of the ship heard that. What's going on?
I got that copy of Hagakure and it's frustrating me.
In what way?
Couple problems, Kanchou. First, it's in very old Japanese. Second, I think it's incomplete. Third, it's vague and contradictory on the best day.
Here, listen to this. "Bushido is realized in the presence of death. This means choosing death whenever there is a choice between life and death. There is no other reasoning."
What by Enma's beard is that supposed to mean?
I mean, the obvious meaning is pretty brutal, but that doesn't seem right to me.

Fields.MenuText: Well, what's the context for that quote?
Sounds like the author thinks of bushido as a death cult or something.
Maybe you're reading it wrong, and it's about facing death without fear. Something more reasonable.

Fields.DialogueText: That is exactly my problem, Kanchou. There's not much context available.
Right, but that doesn't sound... right to me. I don't want my sailors eager to die. I want warriors, not corpses.
That sounds better, at the very least.
This study is getting more frustrating than I thought.
I think I'm going to have to get deeper on this. Maybe expand my research a bit. Compare bushido with other warrior codes, perhaps.
I think your diligence is admirable, but maybe you should--
*ALARM*
Never mind.
Race you to the bridge!
@BATTLE
That's an intense look on your face. Did the bulkhead do something to offend you?
Oh, Kanchou - what do you mean?
If you stare any harder at that bulkhead, you're going to burn a hole in it.
Sumimasen, Kanchou. I was lost in thought.
More on your bushido studies?
Hai. I was given another book, this one by a Nitobe Inazo. It was written for Westerners first, but the Japanese government has been promoting it in the last few decades.
Kanchou, I feel like the bushido in this book is very different from the one I know. Or the one in the Hagakure.
It reminds me of chivalry in the Arthurian myth cycle.
Don't let certain British Belles catch you calling it a myth, but go on.
Well, chivalry itself was more or less combat etiquette, according to the records. It morphed to include all the social etiquette stuff over time.
Not too different from bushido, as I understand it. Most martial philosophies seem to involve conduct off the field of battle, too.
Right, but I find that chivalry is greatly romanticized in Arthurian lore. To what end, I'm not sure. I feel like Nitobe-san has done similarly with bushido.

Fields.MenuText: But you said the Japanese government has been promoting his work, right?
Hmm. I suppose there's a certain amount of drift over time.
How big a shift are we talking here?

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. It's become core to a lot of the bushido they teach to the Imperial armed forces.
Of course, but I don't consider romanticizing something to be "drift."
Big enough that it concerns me. It seems less... nuanced, perhaps. More absolute.
Maybe I'm just... old.
You're fairly young as warships go.
True. But my roots, my spirit, are planted in the soil of Mount Ashigara. Where legends once roamed...
Perhaps because of that, I feel older than I am sometimes.
I can feel echoes of ages long past, like the Sengoku Jidai, when Japan was finally unified.
I need to think about this more. I just can't put my finger on what's wrong.
*ALARM*
... Convenient. I was just thinking I could use a little exercise.
Even when you're subdued and contemplative, you're ready for a fight, eh?
You can bet on that, Kanchou! Korrrrraaa!
@BATTLE
Let's wrap this up, my fine wolves! They're on the run!
@BATTLE
Do you have a moment, Kanchou? I just had a thought while we were securing from battle stations.
I always have time for you, Ashigara. What's on your mind?
Are you familiar with the tale of the forty-seven ronin? The Ako incident?
Refresh my memory.
A daimyo named Asano was forced to commit seppuku at the demand of an obnoxious, pompous, and corrupt courtier of the shogun.
While forbidden from taking revenge, the lord's samurai, now made ronin by the death of their lord, planned vengeance anyway to honor his dying wish.
The ronin dispersed and spent more than a year gambling, whoring, drinking... acting like they were utterly disgraced.
All an act to lure the courtier into a false sense of security, of course. When the time was right, their blow would strike true.
After two years of planning, they struck on a snowy day, fought through the courtier's retainers, and found him cowering and groveling.
They took his head to Sengaku-ji Temple in Edo and laid it on their master's grave. Then they turned themselves in.
Revenge was against the wishes of the shogun, so their lives were forfeit. But the people pleaded for their lives, for they had acted honorably for their lord.
The shogun agreed. So he allowed them to honorably commit seppuku and had them buried next to their master.
Now, Tsunetomo, the author of the Hagakure, says the forty-seven were failures. They didn't strike immediately, even if it meant their death.
Success isn't what matters in that case. It's striking swiftly and bravely, even if you should fail. I'm not sure what I think of that.

Fields.MenuText: What's the point of bloodshed if you don't succeed? Surely avenging their lord was the right thing to do.
Tsunetomo has a point, perhaps. The ronin may have been focused on success to the exclusion of their calling.
I think your thoughts on this are more important than mine.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree completely.
He's not wrong in that regard. But even his contemporaries seem to seem to vehemently disagree.
What I think...
The ronin accepted greater risk and greater damage to their honor to ensure success. I think that's valiant.
There's no point in loosing an arrow if it doesn't strike true. No point in death if your goal remains unfulfilled.
Even if you do your duty by dying?
If your back isn't literally against a wall, and there's still a chance to succeed... why settle for an honorable death?
I guess it says a lot about society that the story's endured the way it has.
Society can be wrong. But loyalty and courage can't be.
Captain, a moment?
What is it?
Have you noticed the condition of the crew recently?
They seem a bit quieter than normal. I figured it was fatigue. We've seen a lot of combat.
Perhaps partially. But the Japanese crew feel as if Ashigara's abandoned them.
How's that? It's not like she's missed a call to battle stations.
True, and that's what's keeping morale strong. But she's not attended meals or training sessions with the crew for some time.
The yubitsume demand shook a few of them, I think. There was no doubt it was just, but their Ane-san withdrawing from them has perhaps... exacerbated things.
It's possible that they think she considers them unworthy of their presence.

Fields.MenuText: That's preposterous.
She's been spending her whole time studying to be better for them.
I think this issue's getting out of hand.

Fields.DialogueText: To you and I, perhaps, but...
That isn't something we've made clear, out of respect for her privacy.
Then you must see to it.
In the end, none of us can help with this matter. You're the Captain. It falls to you.
I know. I'll see to it. Reassure them for now as best you can. Ashigara is still with us.
You were a good choice for her, Captain. You're not half bad at this.
Even with her avatar not walking among us, she's quite possibly closer to us than ever before.
Now to work out how to get Ashigara back on track.
*ALARM*
... Right after I deal with this.
@BATTLE
Ashigara! There you are. I've been looking all over for you.
Oi, what's this? You falling for me or something? You're following me around like a puppy.
Har har. I've been trying to find you most of the day.
Yare yare. You should know better than that, Kanchou. We're within my body. Call. I will come.
I was just about to look for you, though. I have a question for you.
My research shows me two types of honor. There's internal honor - that's the kind found in bushido.
It comes from having a code, holding yourself to a standard. It doesn't require others to know your deeds.
Then there's a Western conception of honor - a more public thing. Quite different from Japan.
How your deeds define you as an individual and as a part of the community - all of that goes into that perception of honor. Which of the two would you say matters most?

Fields.MenuText: Internal honor. What others say doesn't matter. Holding strong to your vows, ideals, and convictions does.
External honor. What good are words without deeds? Oaths only matter when pledged to others.
In my own experience, the types of people we call heroes balance both.

Fields.DialogueText: Well said. I certainly can appreciate the concept native to my homeland.
Hmm. Oaths do matter in bushido, but the weight behind them seems balanced differently.
A good point indeed. Though it could just be you being indecisive, eh, Kanchou?
Hmm. I'll take that into consideration.
I feel like I'm getting closer to understanding what I want to show the crew. Not just being fierce, or brave, or wild and free.
I want to embody the spirit of the warrior properly. I need to take care of my pack. I need to be better for them. More for them.
Ashigara, about that. I--
*ALARM*
I really just can't finish a sentence, can I?
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I--
Let me guess. You have another question.
Kisama! Lemme finish, dammit... but yes. I have another question.
Well, go on then.
I've been considering the concept of embracing death more.
It seems so fundamental to bushido, even if what that means isn't clear.
I'm still working on it, but in the immediate term... does embracing death mean not living?

Fields.MenuText: I recall the samurai living pretty passionately.

Fields.DialogueText: True. With discipline, but hardly giving up life's pleasures. From the simple to the more... base.

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't seem like that's the case. Bushido is a warrior code, not a death cult. Right?

Fields.DialogueText: That's what it feels like to me. Hard to tell where the legacy ends and modern influence begins.

Fields.MenuText: On philosophical questions like this, what matters is your answer to that question, not mine.

Fields.DialogueText: Huh? You're just going to cop out on me, Kanchou?
I don't like the idea of teaching my soldiers to embrace death by not living.
Seems... wrong. In a lot of ways. But I want to lead them along the path I feel like I was meant to be a guide on.
Guides show the way... hopefully the right way. Who could know the path better than a kami?
A kami who knows what she's talking about, presumably.
Maybe it's just that bushido's changed over the centuries... but that doesn't mean your way is wrong.
Respect, duty, loyalty, compassion, honesty, courage, and honor...
None of those scream "crave death" to me. Nor does Zen Buddhism teach that.
If those core values of bushido are the old way... then I'll walk the old path.
Glad to hear it. The world can always use more people preaching compassion, duty, courage, and honor.
Those other three virtues are just as important.
As you say, o wise and benevolent Ashigara-no-Kami.
You know, goddess or not, it's probably not wise to tease someone with a wide variety of naval rifles at her command.
You'd never hurt me. Not unless I deserved it. I don't think you'd really hurt anyone for nothing.
You're a wolf. Wolves fight and kill to eat and to survive. Nothing more. Nothing less.
Yeah... yeah, you're right. You're--
*ALARM*
Sounds like an excellent opportunity to hurt someone who deserves it.
Well, by all means, let's go!
@BATTLE
Out of my way, Funayūrei! And the rest of you, don't crowd me!
@BATTLE
You chased some of the lookouts off again.
Needed to meditate again.
At least you don't look nearly as grave this time.
I don't feel grave. Nor happy. Just... peaceful, perhaps.

Fields.MenuText: Been in the good sake again, eh?

Fields.DialogueText: No! Well, yes. But I didn't find this serenity at the bottom of a bottle.

Fields.MenuText: That's generally what happens when you tackle the great problems head on.

Fields.DialogueText: I wonder. I suppose running out of energy and surrendering to the great questions is a kind of peace.

Fields.MenuText: Peace, eh? Seems like that's a precious commodity these days.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed. Perhaps you'd care to sit down and join me in some?
So. Any storm clouds darkening these clear skies of yours?
Just one. We've discussed it before. We're going to lose more people before this is over. I worry about them.
We will, for you and me. That's our role. Our duty. To shelter and treasure the lives entrusted to us.
And... when needed... to sell those lives dearly, but without hesitation. To let those who can't defend themselves live in peace.
Which is all the more reason to remember our fallen... but celebrate life too.
Then we'll just have to give it our all and make sure every day we have is a good one.
I'm going to stay up here a bit longer. Smoke my kiseru, perhaps. Care to join me, Kanchou? You're usually good company.
All right. Can't say I've got anything pressing to get to.
The life unexamined... one of the sailors said that the other day. Struck me as a bit sad, really.
I'm sure it's peaceful in a way... but so much of what makes life good would pass you by.
I think that's part of the nature of Kami. Most of us are like humans, but we're... more. More... emotionally intense.
I think it's because this is the first chance we've really had to live - and not just in the hearts of our crews.
All the more reason to live with all you have.
Hah! I'll drink to that... and I just happen to have some of that good sake.
Fine. Just a touch, though. I'm on duty.
And I'm the ship. It'll be fine. Besides, like you said, we have to celebrate life as it happens.
Kanchou, I need to talk to you. I think I figured it out. The whole embracing-death thing.
*ALARM*
It'll have to wait. Don't embrace it quite yet.
@BATTLE
All right, go on. What did you come to understand?
I understand that a lot of people have the reading comprehension of a koi.
Embracing death doesn't mean having a death wish. The Norse allegedly had a similar view of death to the Japanese, right?
So I did some digging. All I could find doesn't mean you want to die or need to die.
It's facing the inevitable with courage. Doing everything you can to accomplish your goals.
Or as the Norsemen put it, "The skein of your fate was known at the moment of your birth."

Fields.MenuText: So if the moment of your death is known...

Fields.DialogueText: Then all you can do is face your time with courage and live boldly until then.

Fields.MenuText: That fits nicely for me. You will die. This is known. May as well make it memorable.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Come into this world screaming and covered in blood... why not go out the same way, right?

Fields.MenuText: Still seems a bit dark in tone to my way of thinking.

Fields.DialogueText: In the end, Kanchou, we can't run from our end. We can only lean into it and face it like wolves.
I'm getting close. Thank you for your health and patience, Kanchou.
You're been doing it all yourself. I just work here.
... I didn't want to rush you, Ashigara, but maybe I should have.
I wanted you to find your way in your own time, but the crew's hurting.
What? Those guys can't be that down, can they?
I told you, the crew's getting more Japanese on the whole in behavior. And the Japanese crew think you're not around as much anymore because you've deemed them unworthy.
Those... those morons! Graaaaah. Fine. I'll deal with this.
I'm counting on it.
Hell's fires, you and the first officer are correct. Things are way worse than I expected.
With our operational tempo high... I guess I should have expected it.
I suppose I just thought they were a bit tougher than that.
They look to you for guidance, for strength. When they see you off scared or worried...
Right. They figure they need to be scared or worried, too. Dammit!

Fields.MenuText: Glad you're finally working on the same page.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, yeah. Rub it in, why don't you?

Fields.MenuText: So. Ideas? We've been without our Kami. Now that you're back...

Fields.DialogueText: That's just it! I was never gone! Damn it all.

Fields.MenuText: How in the world do we fix this, Ashigara?

Fields.DialogueText: I... I'm thinking. I'm thinking!
I kinda want to give them all a decent thrashing.
The beatings will continue until morale improves.
Ooh, catchy. Probably not the right move, though.
No, probably not. Doesn't match your new enlightened attitude, either.
Grrrrr. Violence is so much easier, Kanchou.
They're not even calling me Ane-san anymore!
What are they calling you?
Kami-sama, mostly. They're groveling a bit, too. Some left offerings at my door.
Anything good?
Sake, tobacco, some sweets. These jackasses know me, at least.
What to do... Wait. Duh. I know.
I'm not sure I like that look on your face.
What, this look? This is my problem-solving face, Kanchou.
It's the face you get when you're about to put a point-blank salvo into a Morgana.
Like I said. Problem-solving.
I got this, Kanchou. You just sit back and let Ane-san square this away.
I made this mess, and I'm gonna get us out of it. That's a promise.
... Why do I have a sudden sense of foreboding?
*ALARM*
Oh. That makes more sense than Ashigara's morale program. There's a fight on our hands!
@BATTLE
KORRRRRAAA! Cut! Cut! Cut!
Lot of noise from up on deck. I feel like I need to go investigate.
Cut! Come on, Takemori, the yōkai ain't like the geishas in port! They're not gonna just lay down for you out of pity. Strike!
Attention on deck!
Hah? Oh, Kanchou! All right, you miscreants, Kanchou's brought you mercy and reprieve. Take five.
Dare I ask what's going on?
Kenjutsu, of course. Figured that'd be obvious from all the swords.
Uh-huh. Skip the sass and tell me what you're up to.
Boo. you're no fun sometimes, Kanchou. Well, it's like I said. Morale improvement.
I need to get back in with the crew. Get them fighting fit again. Figure I'll start by getting them working up a sweat!

Fields.MenuText: Starting with the body, then going for the mind?
I suppose a hard workout does a good job of getting your mind off things.
Kind of disappointed you didn't ask me to join.

Fields.DialogueText: Precisely, Kanchou.
Always worked for me.
If you want a private lesson, all you have to do is ask.
Well, I can certainly see you're working them hard. I'm seeing a lot of smiles despite all that.
Of course! I'm back with them, doing our routine.
Harder than normal, mind, but a return to "normal" even in weird circumstances--
Like the middle of a war.
... Can make most people start bouncing back from a low point.
Not to worry, Kanchou, I got this. Say, want to join us? Maybe have a bout with me?
A bout with you? Ashigara, that sounds--
*ALARM*
--Like it's going to have to wait! To your stations!
More fool them to attack when my blood's already up!
@BATTLE
Kooorraaa! Send 'em all back to whatever hell they crawled out of!
@BATTLE
Right, good. So the three of you start telling lots of stories, got me? Now scram.
What kind of stories would these be?
Damn, you move around super sneaky when you want to, Kanchou. You gotta be a wolf too!
No, you're just loud. What are you up to?
Fine, ruin the surprise. Those sailors are the unofficial historians on the crew.
Muyo, Jeddermann, and Gozen. Jeddermann even fancies himself a skáld.
Skáld?
Some sorta Norse warrior poet. He can recite all these sagas about heroes from memory.
What's the play here?
It's like this. I want to teach bushido, but not in a classroom.
So I figure I get those three telling good stories to bored sailors and let things sink in naturally.

Fields.MenuText: That's actually rather clever, Ashigara.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to sound that surprised, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like it'll still need a little supplemental education.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure, but that's easier if the foundations are there to build on.

Fields.MenuText: Making warriors via storytelling, eh?

Fields.DialogueText: Every warrior culture I could find books on had a strong storytelling culture, including Japan. I figure that's no coincidence.
This is just stage two of my master plan.
You have a plan? Who are you and what have you done with Ashigara?
Don't make me bite you, Kanchou.
All right, all right. So what's the rest of the plan?
Gonna let the regular physical training and stories sink in a bit.
Then I'll be working on a little ceremony.
I ain't telling you details, so don't ask. Just get your dress uniform ready. With a sword. If for some godsforsaken reason you don't have one, I'll fix that.
All right, Ashigara. I'll play along.
Just keep trusting me, Kanchou. You won't regret it.
Come on! Clear 'em out! I don't have time for these cows today!
@BATTLE
All right, Ashigara. I'm here in my full dress uniform, complete with sword. What's this plan?
We're going to have ourselves a little ceremony, Kanchou.
Rededicate ourselves to each other, to the pack, and to crushing oni.
So all I need you to do is wait here till I call for you.
The whole crew - even the watch - is going to do sakizuke again, in order, from their sections on up.
The section leaders will join me on deck, along with an audience of a hundred or so.
I'll do sakizuke with them, accepting their pledges on behalf of their sections.
Then you'll come out and do sakizuke with me again, formalizing my oath and their oaths to you.

Fields.MenuText: The naval chain of command really isn't good enough, eh?
Are we all going to howl at the moon after?
What comes after that?

Fields.DialogueText: Not personal enough, if you ask me.
Ho! Nice idea, Kanchou! Write that down!
Food, drink, some special mourning services by the shrine. Nothing big.
All right, I think it's just about time. Read that paper there while you wait.
Let's see what she left for me. A poem? Interesting.
A lone wolf's howl echoes in the night.
It mourns what once was.
It calls for what is still to come.
Though others may pass me by.
May my steel stand testament to them.
As their lives stand testament to me.
Heh. She really is more than you'd expect. Sentimental, too.
I think I hear her calling. All right. Showtime.
KOORRRAAA! Get out of the way, damn you!
@BATTLE
Don't drag me, Ashigara. I'm coming!
Nice to see you in such bright spirits. You've been a bit moody recently.
Oi, what kinda crap's that? I just had some things to work out. I'm still me.
I think you even stopped drinking for a while there.
I didn't. I just... started drinking alone for a bit. Probably not the right call.
It usually never is.
So you're volunteering to drink with me from now on, then?
Good company. Cheap, drinks. Possibly free, depending on how I cook the budget.

Fields.MenuText: What's in it for me?
I suppose. Can't let you get into trouble without me.
We're packmates, aren't we? I thought that was just part of the deal.

Fields.DialogueText: Trouble? Me? Neeeever.
Oh, it is. But it's nice to hear you say it out loud, Kanchou.
Say, Ashigara... ever decide on a satisfactory answer? About the afterlife?
Pfft. Now who's the morbid one? As a matter of fact, I did.
Besides embracing my fate... and fighting till the very end...
My hope is that all of us - in the next world, or life, whatever...
We'll meet where the wild wolves have gone. We'll run together in those mountains forever.
Sounds peaceful.
It's always been in my dreams on some level.
How so?
I don't know if I dream like humans do. But when I dream, I dream of running through the snow on Mount Ashigara.
My four paws digging into earth I've never set foot on, the scent of prey in my nose...
No more war. No more yōkai to hunt. Just... the hunt, and the pack around me.
Sounds perfect for you. Don't go hunting too early, though. We have work to do.
Damn right. I don't know if a warship can die of old age, but I'm going to try.
Heh. Some people talk about dying in your bed as if it's a bad thing. I just see it as proof of strength.
Oh? Now this logic I have to hear.
Simple. Someone who's old and feeble, that no one's got the guts to face... who could be stronger than that person?
Now, enough hot air. Come on! I need some exercise and you're the perfect sparring partner!
